The prisoner came there and asked us to buy two pairs of cucumber lights, and on the Saturday night my master did not agree to buy them, but he asked to leave them there till Monday; he did not come again till Wednesday morning - I then told him that they had been claimed; he said they were his own, and proposed to take them away; I said, I heard a gentleman had lost them, and till the gentleman came I should not part with them; he then asked if I would purchase them - I said No, unless my master consented.

WILLIAM HUMPHRIES
. I keep the Marquis of Lansdown, in Thomas-street, Hackney-road. I missed these on Saturday week, but they were taken to the witness two or three days before that - my premises are a quarter of a mile from Mr. Rawlings.

GEORGE AVERY
(Police-constable G 175.) I took the prisoner; he said he knew nothing about them.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had purchased the articles of a man he had worked with.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Confined Six Months .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1105.
HANNAH BURKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 2 shawls, value 25s.; 2 caps, value 3s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 10s.; 1 gown, value 1s. 6d., and 1 pair of gloves, value 6d., the goods of
William Chard
, her master .

WILLIAM CHARD
. I live in Little Queen-street, Edgware-road
. The prisoner had been my servant about three months; between four and five o'clock in the morning of the 4th of January she left, and we missed these articles; in consequence of information, about three weeks after, we went to No. 64, South Molton-street, and the prisoner came to the door with my wife's gown on; I left her in charge - the night before she left us, my wife found herin bed with some person; she ran up to me, but when I got there, the person was gone; I went round the house at one o'clock, and there was no person there but the prisoner, who was asleep, and between four and five she came to our room for a light.

WILLIAM BLOOMFIELD
(Police-constable D 9.) I went to No. 64, South Molton-street; the prisoner opened the door - the prosecutor said he wanted to speak to her; she made no answer; we went into the passage, and then took her up stairs, and the mistress claimed a shawl, a gown, and a cap, which she had on; Mr. Chard lost some money and a reticule - this is the shawl; the prisoner tore up a gown of her own before me and the prosecutor.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported Seven Years .

1106.
GEORGE BLACKWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 2 sheets, value 4s., and 1 napkin, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Lawrence
.

THOMAS LAWRENCE
. I keep a house at No.3. Charles-court, St. Martin's-lane
. I let it out to single men furnished; the prisoner took a lodging of me last Wednesday week, the 4th of April; he came the next day, and staid two nights - on Saturday morning I was awoke by one of my lodgers calling to him, and asking if that was his napkin which was hanging out of his pocket; I got up, but before I was dressed, he had got him back into my house, with the two sheets and the napkin.

THOMAS CURRY
. About a quarter past five o'clock, on Saturday morning last, I heard the prisoner coming down stairs; I opened my room door, and bade him good morning; as he was going down the next flight of stairs I saw part of a napkin hanging out of his pocket - I opened the street door, and said, "Master, does that belong to you?" he turned and said, "No, no;" I followed him, and asked him again; he said, "Say nothing about it, I have got a sheet;" he took off his hat, and there was a sheet - he then went back; I called the prosecutor; he went up into his room, and I went up after him - he had his clothes unbuttoned; I said, "You have another sheet round your body," but I did not see it.

Prisoner. I had not got out of the court. Witness. Yes, you had, and ran - when I first spoke he did not make me any answer; I then spoke to him again, and he said, "No, no, we will go and have a little coffee."

THOMAS RYALL
(Police-constable F 112.) I took the prisoner, and have the property.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

1107.
MARY EMERY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 1 looking-glass, value 1s. 6d.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s. 6d., and 1 quilt, value 3s. , the goods of
John Stigwood
.

JANE STIGWOOD
. I am the wife of John Stigwood. The prisoner and her husband occupied some apartments of mine - we found some duplicates in their room, and missed some property - the pawnbroker is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

108.
ELEANOR HAMILTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of April , 1 morocco case, value 1s. 6d., and 12 pairs of ear-drops, value 4l. 18s. , the goods of
John Pierce
.

CAROLINE PIERCE
. I am the sister of
John Pierce
- we occupy a first floor in Rabere-street
; I make child-bed linen. The prisoner was in my service; she left me without notice on the 2nd of April, and the next day I missed a dozen pairs of coral drops; my brother carves them - they were in a drawer in the room we worked; the prisoner did not sleep there.
JOHN PIERCE. I know these drops; they were in my care - I had them to carve.

RICHARD CHARLES
HAMMOND. I am shopman to Mr. Edwards, a pawnbroker, at Hoxton. I have four pairs of coral drops, in a case, pawned by the prisoner, on the 2nd of April, about nine o'clock in the evening, for 4s.

MARY WELLINGS
. The prisoner lodged with me; she came home on Monday night, the 2nd of April, and said she had got some coral drops to take to be carved for her master - she asked my daughter to go with her, and she went away directly; I did not see her again till Wednesday - I said, "What have you done?" she began to cry, and said she was very sorry - I said, "You had better go to the station-house, your master and mistress have been here;" she was in great distress.
GUILTY. Aged 18.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor .
Confined One Hour .

1109.
MARY HAINES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 2 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
Charles Livings
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

1110.
HENRY JONES
and
SOPHIA MORGAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of April
. 1 box, value 1s.; 2 sheets, value 3l.; 2 pillow-cases, value 2s.; 6 tablecloths, value 10s.; 7 napkins, value 3s.; 13 towels, value 5s.; 3 shirts, value 6s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 30s.; 5 pairs of stockings, value 5s.; 6 shifts, value 12s.; 1 habitshirt, value 1s., and 1 waistcoat, value 1s. , the goods of
Frederick Beauclerk
, Esq., commonly called Lord Frederick Beauclerk; and
HARRIET BIRD
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen : against the Statute, &c.

ELIZABETH TIPPLE
. I am school-room maid, in the service of Lord
Frederick Beauclerk
- he lives at St. Michael's, near St. Alban's. I packed up a box, containing the articles stated - they belonged to Lord Beauclerk's children; I saw the footman cord the box - it was to be sent by the carrier to Fitzroy-square, London; this is the box - I saw it afterwards at Marlborough-street; these are the articles - I have no doubt whatever of them; they are worth from 10l. to 15l.

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD
. I am an officer of Marlborough-street. On the 3rd of April I went with
James Williams
to No. 13, Hopkin-street - I saw a great light through the key-hole of a room on the first floor; I looked through the key-hole, and saw a box and some linen - I knocked at the door; it was not opened, but the light was put out - I heard the window move; I broke open the door, and went in; I saw Jones and Morgan standing in the room, and Bird getting under the bed - I asked how the box came there; they said George Falkingham had left it there, and that was all they knew about it; I found some duplicates in theroom - Bird said she had pawned the articles by order of Jones and George Falkingham; I found no duplicates on either of the prisoners - I found two shirts on the floor with the wristbands cut off and the collars cut down; I looked out at the window, and saw a barrow, which proved to be stolen; I do not think any one could have got out of the window, as I had men watching - part of the box was burning when I went into the room.

JAMES WILLIAMS
. I am footman to Lady Dillon, who lives in Fitzroy-square
. On the 3rd of April the St. Alban's carrier brought this box there - I took it in, and put it into the front hall; it was corded at the time - Morgan and Jones came there about one o'clock the same afternoon - I had not seen them before; Morgan gave me a bit of paper, and asked if it was right; I said Yes - she said she came from Mrs. Falkingham, and I helped her with the box to a barrow, which was standing at the door; when I got it there she asked if there was any basket; I said No- Jones then wheeled away the barrow, and I went in doors; I went with Schofield, about ten o'clock, and saw what he has stated; some of the things were on the floor and some in the box - the prisoners were all in the room; it was about half a mile from Fitzroy-square.

ANN FALKINGHAM
. I am the wife of
William Falkingham
; we live in Swinnie-place, Lisson-grove - I am a laundress, and wash for Lord Beauclerk; the things are sent every week to Lady Dillon's, in Fitzroy-square; I never employed either of the prisoners to fetch any linen from there. I lost my barrow on Monday evening, the 2nd of April, from a garden, in front of my house; I had seen Jones before, but had no acquaintance with him.
Jones. I can prove that her son resides at Hopkins-street, and they were his things that were there. Witness. It is my son-in-law - I do not know where he lodges; his name is George.

EDWARD NATHAN
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in Cambridge-street, Golden-square. I have a table-cloth, pawned by Bird - I had not known her before, but I am sure she is the woman; I lent 4s. on it, in the name of
Elizabeth Reed
, No. 20, Compton-street.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Jones' Defence The laundress' son made his escape out of window - I inquired of him for a lodging, as I was out of work; he gave me leave to lodge there two or three nights, and on the Tuesday, he asked me to go and fetch the box of linen for him, which he was in the habit of doing- I went there, and took the wheelbarrow, which he went and got from his mother's; Morgan went with me - I wheeled it to Warren-street, and he there took the barrow of me; I returned home in the evening about ten minutes before the officer came; when he heard them come up, he blew the light out himself, got out of the window, and through a dust-hole; I had no suspicion that any thing was wrong - he said he was going to take the things to his mother's the next day.

ANN FALKINGHAM
. I had sent George for the linen about six weeks before this, but he has left me, and got into bad company.
Morgan's Defence. He asked me to go and get the linen, which I did.
Bird's Defence. George Falkingham asked me to pawn the things - I did not know they were stolen; he said they were his mother's.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

MORGAN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

BIRD -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1111.
LOUISA MANTCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 1 watch, value 2l.; 2 seals, value 10s., and 1 watch-key, value 5s. , the goods of
Henry Head
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1112.
JOHN MURPHY
and
JAMES JOHNSTONE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 shovel, value 2s. , the gooods of
Charles Syred
.

CHARLES SYRED. I am a gardener , and live in Richmond-street, Lisson-grove. I was getting some gravel at a house in South-bank
on the 7th of April; I left my shovel while we carried some gravel in - my man said the shovel was stolen; I ran out, and saw the prisoners drawing a water-cart - I followed them, and saw the shovel in the cart; I followed on to Lisson-grove, where I saw the officer, and told him - I then turned, and saw Murphy putting the shovel further into the cart, more out of sight - the officer took them.
Murphy's Defence. A little boy put the shovel on the water-cart, and told us to take it to the yard.
Johnstone's Defence. We were going home a little before twelve o'clock - I kept hold of the handle of the truck, till the officer stopped us; I do not know what was in it.

CHARLES SYRED
. Their faces were both turned from the truck when I saw them, and Murphy was the only one I saw handle the shovel; I said to him, "You have a shovel belonging to me;" he said, "I believe there is one:" I said, "You know there is, you have just put it out of sight."

DANIEL LOCK
. (Police-constable D 42.) I was applied to by the prosecutor, and took the prisoners - this shovel was put into the place where the water is let in.

MURPHY -
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Confined Six Months .

JOHNSTONE -
NOT GUILTY .

1113.
MARY ANN WARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 5 half-crowns, 3 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Thomas Brown
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1114.
MORGAN O'BRYAN
. was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 1 pair of boots, value 8s. , the goods of
John Howard
.

GEORGE STONE
. (Police-constable C 99.) On Saturday evening, the 31st of March, I was in St. Martin's-court
, and saw the prisoner looking into Mr. Howard's shopwindow - I watched him for five minutes; he put his hand inside the shop door, and took up a pair of Blucher boots - he ran along towards the bottom of the court; I overtook him, and took them from his hand.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he go insidethe shop? A. No - he took them by putting his hand inside the door: they were on a shelf.

SAMUEL COLLIS
. I am assistant to Mr.
John Howard
, No. 36. St. Martin's-court - these are his boots.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going up the court, and saw them at the door - I took them up, and the officer took me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Three Weeks .

1115.
MARGARET HUDDART PALMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , 1 silver spoon, value 4s. , the goods of
James Fogg
.

JAMES FOGG
. I am a Police-surveyor , and live in Martha-street, St. George's
; I have employed the prisoner to make clothes for me. On Sunday, the 26th of February, she brought home a pair of trousers: I told her to take them back to alter - I had two silver tea-spoons on the sideboard, and when she was gone I missed one; I found it at a pawnbroker's - I met her on the Wednesday following, and asked what she had done with the spoon; she made no answer; I told her I found it was at the pawnbroker's, and asked for the duplicate; she said she had destroyed it.

WILLIAM COOMBE
. I was shopman to Mr. Watts, of Hereford-place, Commercial-road. I have a spoon, pawned on the 27th of February, by the prisoner, for 2s.(Property produced and sworn to)
The prisoner pleaded poverty, and received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1116.
JAMES CHARLES PEARCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 1 pair of boots, value 22s.; 2 coats, value 20s.; 2 jackets, value 6s.; 1 smockfrock, value 6d., and 1 waistcoat, value 1s. , the goods of
John Towersey
.

JOHN TOWERSEY. I am a post-boy , and live in Oxfordshire. On the 4th of April I was at my master's stable at Tetsworth
; I left the articles stated in the stable - I missed them the next morning; I mentioned my loss to
John Berry
, a post-boy, on his way to Uxbridge; I saw a waistcoat taken off the prisoner's back on the Friday following, before the Magistrate at Uxbridge - that was one that I had lost.

JOHN BERRY
. In consequence of hearing of the loss I made inquiry at Uxbridge; I found the prisoner, and had him taken into custody - I found on him a pair of boots and a frock; these are them.

GEORGE JEWELL
. I saw the prisoner at Uxbridge - he offered me this jacket; I bought it of him for 12s., with this waistcoat.

JOHN BROWN
. I have a blue jacket which I bought on the 5th, of the prisoner, at Uxbridge, which is twenty-seven miles from where the prosecutor lives.

THOMAS ALMAN
. I bought a coat of the prisoner for 16s. and a pot of beer, at Uxbridge.

WILLIAM INGRAM
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; he had a smock-frock and a pair of boots on - I found a stall-man, to whom the prisoner had sold a great coat; I said I would take it - the stallman said, "Let him give me my money, 4s. 6d.," and he gave it him out of his purse - I saw a piece of gold in his purse; I took him to the White Hart, and searched him, but I could not find any gold - I asked him to open his month, and I found this sovereign in it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
JOHN TOWERSEY. I found these things on the Friday- they had been sold on the Thursday - I left them safe on the Wednesday night, at half-past eleven o'clock; we found 1l. 7s. 3d. on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming through Brentford on Wednesday morning; I met a man, and bought the things of him.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1116.
WILLIAM DEAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 10 spoons, value 30s., the goods of
Benjamin Best
, his master .

BENJAMIN BEST
. I am a coal-merchant - the prisoner was my errand-boy . I missed some spoons, and asked him about them; he denied it; I told him it would be better to tell the truth - I saw a spoon in Old-street, but could not swear to it.

HUGH FISHER STANGER
. I bought a spoon of two men, but the prosecutor gave it back to me, and I melted it.
NOT GUILTY .

1117.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of March , 1 cloak, value 12s., and 1 shawl, value 3s. , the goods of
Timothy Kalahan
.

ANN LYON
. I lodge in Short's-gardens, Drury-lane
. On the 4th of April I met the prisoner in Long-acre, and in consequence of information, I asked him for some duplicates; he said he was the wrong person, and he went on; I followed him, and said he had robbed Timothy Kalahan, and if he did not give me the duplicates, I would have him taken up - he gave me the duplicates, and I gave him into custody.

MARY KALAHAN
. I am the wife of
Timothy Kalahan
; we live in Short's-gardens. The prisoner lodged with us; I found one of my boxes broken open, and missed a shawl and a cloak.

EDWARD NEWSHEAD
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker, in Tothill-street. I have a cloak, pawned on the 14th of March, in the name of
William Smith
, by a person like the prisoner, but I cannot swear to him; this is the duplicate.

WILLIAM GEORGE FRY
. I am in the service of Mr. Lorton, a pawnbroker. I have a shawl, but did not take it in; this is the duplicate of it.

JOSEPH MAYS
(Police-constable E 63.) I took the prisoner, and got these duplicates from Lyon.
Prisoner's Defence. I worked as a carpenter for the prosecutor; he owed me a little money, and would not pay me - I pawned the things, and gave up the duplicates.

TIMOTHY KALAHAN
. I had employed him, but I do not owe him a farthing.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Six Months .

1118.
ELLEN CONNELLAN
and
WILLIAM WILSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of March , 1 jacket, value 20s.; 1 waistcoat, value 7s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
James Bradshaw
, from his person .

JAMES BRADSHAW
. I am a seaman , and lodge in Martha-street. On the night of the 22nd of March I went to the Crooked Billet; I saw Connellan there - I got drunk, and she took my clothes off me; I found myself the next morning at the Police-station - my jacket, waistcoat, and handkerchief were gone; I did not see Wilson - I took Connellan there to drink.

MATTHEW POULTER
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker. I have a jacket and a waistcoat, pawned by Connettan, on the 22nd of March, in the name of Jane Smith, at near eight o'clock in the evening, for 17s.

GEORGE LIDDIARD
. I keep the Crooked Billet at the corner of King David-lane
. I saw the prosecutor at my house with Connellan; he got drunk, and fell asleep - I afterwards saw Connellan in company with Wilson and two others; the two prisoners went into the room where the prosecutor was asleep - I then missed the prisoner and the persons who came in with them; I found the prosecutor stripped of his jacket and waistcoat, and laying on the tap-room floor - I went after the prisoners; I took Connellan in three or four minutes - Wilson was with her, but he ran away.

Connellan. Wilson was not in my company. Witness. Yes; Connellan and another woman came about four o'clock- they staid some time and went out; Wilson and another man, and the two women came again - they called for some drink, and gave my boy a bad halfpenny, which he refused; Connellan then came out, and said it was one she had taken there that afternoon - the prisoners then went into the tap-room, where the prosecutor was; I went into my skittle-ground with a pot of beer, and on my return the prisoners were gone; I went out and saw them under a gas-lamp; they saw me, and Wilson ran off.

GEORGE PHILLIPS
(Police-constable K 87.) I took Wilson; I told him it was for a robbery at the Crooked Billet, between him, Connellan, and two more; he said he had never seen the house, and should not know where to go to it - he made some resistance.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Wilson's Defence. I was on board the Repulse on the night of the robbery.

CONNELLAN -
GUILTY . Aged 25.

WILSON -
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1119.
DANIEL CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 2 spoons, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Mary Smith
.

SARAH DUCKETT
. I live with Mrs. Mary Smith in Beaufort-row, Chelsea
- she is a widow . On the 30th of March, about eleven o'clock, as I cleaned the kitchen window, I heard the back door shut, and saw the prisoner going out; he asked if we wanted any lemons, and he had one in his hand - I told him to go round to the back door and wait: he said, No, he would not wait there - I went out of the area, and he went out of the gate and ran; I ran and caught his coat - he struggled with me, and got away, leaving part of his coat in my hand; Mr. Hall took him, and took from his basket two tea-spoons, one silver and one pewter - they are my mistress', and I had seen them at nine o'clock that morning, in the kitchen - I have seen the prisoner selling lemons.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. He did not run away immediately. A. As soon as I got out of the area, he came towards me - I said, "Go round to the back door," he said, "No, I will wait here" - he then went out of the gate; when I went to him he ran.

WILLIAM HALL
. I am an officer. On the 30th of March I was in Beaufort-row; I heard a cry of Thieves! and saw this witness holding the prisoner's coat; he got from her and ran towards Battersea-bridge - I pursued, and took him; I found these spoons in his basket.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1120.
JOHN MEAD
and
ELIZABETH DEVALLION
were indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of February , 12 shirts, value 18s.; 2 shawls, value 6s.; 30 handkerchiefs, value 16s.; 6 pairs of stockings, value 4s.; 6 aprons, value 2s., and 1 table-cloth, value 6s. , the goods of
Henry Phillips
.

MARTHA CONWAY
. I was nursing at the prosecutor's, and washing there. I left some things in the yard, and missed them - I did not see the prisoner there.

EDWARD CHILD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shirt, pawned by a boy, in the name of Mead, for 1s. 3d. - I am not certain who it was.

JAMES GRAHAM
(Police-constable K 49). I took the prisoner; Mead said he took the property, and Devallion was with him - he said he pawned the shift.
Devaltion's Defence. The woman the clothes belong to, told me to go to the pawnbroker's and get an iron, and if we could not get one, to bring the whole chain of them.
NOT GUILTY .

1121.
TIMOTHY MURPHY
and
MARY ALLEN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 hat, value 9s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
Charles Bland
.

ROBERT HAINES
. I keep an eating-house in High-street, Shadwell
. The prisoners came there together at twelve o'clock at night, on the 4th of April; there were two others in company with them, and they called for four basins of soup - they sat in the box in which the prosecutor sat asleep; I noticed them - Allen came in with a straw hat on; he went out with a black one - I went to look at the prosecutor, who lodges with me, and his hat was gone from the table where it had been laying; I suspected the prisoners, and went after them - I saw an officer, and described the parties; he brought Allen back first, and then got Murphy - the prosecutor was still asleep.

CHARLES BLAND
. I am a sailor . I was at the eating-house - I fell asleep. but I was not drunk; when I awoke my hat was gone, and my handkerchief, which had been in it - this is my hat; I did not see the prisoner.

WILLIAM REEVES
(Police-constable K 152.) I had information of this, and went down a dark street - I saw Allen with her hand behind her; I asked what she had got - she said, "My husband's hat;" I said, "How came you to have it?" she said, "I have had a row with him, he threw his hat at me, and ran away;" I took her to theeating-house, with the straw hat which she had in her hand - we left the hat there; she asked me to let her go, and she would find the man - she went on, and I followed her; she called Tim - he said, "Is that you?" she said,"Yes, you have got me into a nice piece of trouble about this hat;" he said, "Where is my hat?" she said, "The Policeman has it:" she went up to him - I followed her, and seized them both; he had no hat on then, but Criper found this hat within a few yards of where I took him.

ROBERT CRIPER
. I am a private watchman. At a quarter before one o'clock I was called to assist the officer, who had the prisoners in charge - we took them to the station; I then went to the lane again, and found this hat, but no handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Murphy's Defence. I was going into the house, and this woman, who was a stranger, was going in; she asked me to treat her, and I did - we then went out, and had some words; I threw my hat at her, and never saw it again.

MURPHY -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Weeks .

ALLEN -
NOT GUILTY .

1122.
SARAH PERROTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 1 watch, value 30s., and 1 watch-key, value 3s. , the goods of
William Miller
.

WILLIAM MILLER
. I am employed on board a ship. I met the prisoner on London-bridge
on the night of the 25th of February, a little before nine o'clock; we went into the Redcross, and sat some time - we came out towards the bridge again; we then went under one of the arches of the bridge - we staid there some time, and then she said she rather expected there was a Policeman at the corner; she went to see - I then missed my watch out of my pocket: I went out, but did not see her - I went on till I saw a watchman, and told him the case - he told me to go the Policeman; I am sure my watch had not fallen out.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you had not much money? A. I had 25s. or 26s.; I had not paid her any thing - I was to have paid her, and should if she had not gone away - I did not give her my watch; it had no case to it - I was to have given her 1s. and something to drink; I might be a little the worse for drink - I cannot say how much I drank: I might be two hours in the public-house - I had pawned the case of my watch.

JAMES LAWSON
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner brought this watch on Monday morning, and wanted to pawn it - she said she had found it on London-bridge; I asked where the case was - she said her husband had broken it, and it was gone to be repaired; my lad then put a paper into my hand, that such a watch had been stolen - the prisoner said she would fetch her husband, and ran out; I pursued and took her.
NOT GUILTY .

1123.
MARY ANN PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of February 1 shawl, value 5s. , the goods of
Harriet Handerside
.

HARRIET HANDERSIDE
. On the 28th of February I was unfortunately in the station-house; I had a shawl on; the prisoner, who was a stranger to me, was there - I was in there for some hours, and while there I lost my shawl; I told the officer of it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you walk to the station? A. I dare say I was taken there for protection, because I would not give my address; the prisoner was tipsy - I do not know which of us was the worst; I was sitting sleeping when I was robbed.

JAMES TITT
(Police-contable G 7.) I took the prisoner down to Worship-street; I then heard of this robbery, and saw the corner of a shawl hanging below the prisoner's gown - I took her back to the prosecutrix, who was at the station; I asked her to describe the shawl, which she did, and when I showed it her, she claimed it.
Cross-examined. Q. Were not the prosecutrix and the prisoner both drunk? A. The prosecutrix was very drunk; the prisoner was not very drunk - she might have been drinking.
Prisoner's Defence. I certainly had the shawl somehow; but I was not in the least conscious of it till I was told of it.
NOT GUILTY .
